data.title: China's Aurora Mobile pops after integrating DeepSeek’s AI image model on platform
data.description:
Shares of Aurora Mobile (NASDAQ:JG) surged about 9% on Wednesday after the company said its enterprise AI agent platform GPTBots.ai has integrated DeepSeek’s (DEEPSEEK) unified multimodal AI model, Janus-Pro, into its ecosystem as an open tool.

This integration follows the recent addition of DeepSeek’s R1 large language model.

Part of DeepSeek’s image model family, Janus-Pro is known for its hyper-realistic outputs, contextual understanding, and seamless style adaptation. Aurora said that by integrating Janus-Pro as an Open Tool, GPTBots will enable businesses to unlock new creative possibilities while streamlining visual content creation.

With the addition of Janus-Pro, GPTBots’ ecosystem now includes a wide range of tools, such as LinkedIn Tools, HubSpot Tools, Google Search Pro, Google Video, WhatsApp API Message and EngageLab Email Sender.

Source: Press Release

data.title: U.S. Postal Service halts inbound parcels from China, Hong Kong
data.description:
The United States Postal Service (USPS) announced a temporary suspension of inbound parcels from China and Hong Kong, effective immediately.

The decision was made public on February 4, 2025, and will remain in place "until further notice." However, this suspension does not affect the delivery of letters and flat mail, which will continue as usual.

The suspension follows recent actions by the U.S. government, including the implementation of a new 10% tariff on Chinese imports and the termination of the "de minimis" exemption. This exemption previously allowed packages valued at less than $800 to enter the U.S. without incurring duties or taxes. The value of de minimis shipments was over 1.36B in 2024.

The elimination of de minimis exemption could have a negative impact on popular e-commerce platforms—Shein, Amazon (AMZN), Alibaba (BABA), Temu, owned by PDD (PDD), among others—which have relied heavily on these shipping advantages to have competitive pricing in the U.S. market.

The USPS has not provided specific reasons for this suspension, but it is widely viewed as a response to broader trade policy changes aimed at tightening regulations on imports from China.

ETFs linked to China: (KWEB), (PGJ), (CQQQ), (FXI), (GXC), (MCHI), (FLCH), (CNYA), (ASHR), (YINN).

Dear readers: We recognize that politics often intersects with the financial news of the day, so we invite you to click here to join the separate political discussion.

data.title: Boeing lost over $2B on Starliner program so far, flags risk of more losses
data.description:
Boeing (NYSE:BA) recorded its biggest annual reach-forward loss related to its Starliner program spacecraft in 2024, and has lost more than $2B since it first secured the nearly $5B fixed-price contract from NASA to develop the spacecraft.

The company increased the program's reach-forward loss by $523M in 2024, reflecting schedule delays and higher testing and certification costs, as well as higher costs for post certification missions.

"At December 31, 2024, we had approximately $398M of capitalized precontract costs and $150M of potential termination liabilities to suppliers related to unauthorized future missions," Boeing (NYSE:BA) disclosed in an SEC filing. "Risk remains that we may record additional losses in future periods."

The first crewed Starliner spaceflight launched last June, and had a minimum mission duration of eight days. However, because of the spacecraft's propulsion issues, NASA decided not to risk the astronauts' safety and Starliner returned to Earth uncrewed last August.

NASA last week reaffirmed that it is working with SpaceX (SPACE) to bring back astronauts Sunita Williams and Butch Wilmore from the International Space Station "as soon as practical."

In October, the agency had said Starliner's next flight would be decided "once a better understanding of Boeing's (BA) path to system certification is established." No updates on the spacecraft have been provided since.

data.title: Apple dips after China mulls potential probe on App Store fees - report
data.description:
China's State Administration for Market Regulation is planning a potential investigation into Apple's (NASDAQ:AAPL) App Store policies and the fees it charges app developers, Bloomberg News reported.

Shares of Apple fell about 2% premarket on Wednesday.

The antitrust watchdog has been reviewing the iPhone maker's policies, which include charging up to 30% on in-app spending and restricting external payment services and stores. The agency's officials have discussed the matter with Apple executives and app developers since last year, the report added.

Apple did not immediately respond to a request for comment from Seeking Alpha.

The discussions come on the back of a long-running tussle between Apple and developers such as Tencent (OTCPK:TCEHY) (OTCPK:TCTZF) and ByteDance (BDNCE) over iOS store policies. Since 2024, China has targeted the practices of U.S. tech companies from Nvidia (NVDA) to most recently Alphabet's (GOOGL) (GOOG) Google.

The regulators may not formally move against Apple if the current talks go well, the report noted.

On Tuesday, China announced today it was investigating Google for allegedly violating an "anti-monopoly law." The Asian country's decision comes after the Trump administration imposed a 10% tariff on Chinese goods. In addition, Beijing announced new tariffs on the import of multiple U.S. products, the latest trade salvo between the two countries.

The Chinese agency thinks that Apple could be charging local developers unreasonably high fees. They think the restricting of third-party app stores and payment methods also hampers competition and hurts domestic consumers, the report noted.

If the U.S. tech giant resists making changes, the Chinese government could launch a formal investigation, the report added.

Apple has been facing heat from regulators globally related to policies of its App store. Earlier this month, the Cupertino, Calif.-based company faced multiple concerns over fees associated with the service in the U.K. and EU. Last year, Apple had revamped its App store in the EU to meet the requirements under the region's the Digital Markets Act.

Apple's first quarter fiscal 2025 results showed that iPhone sales in China fell about 11% year-over-year to around $18B. According to research firm Canalys, the iPhone lost the top spot in China's smartphone market to local rivals, including Vivo and Huawei Technologies.

Last year, a Chinese court agreed to hear a lawsuit filed by a domestic developer against Apple’s commission-charging practices. The US firm is also embroiled in a prolonged talks with Tencent over app store fees that started in 2024, the report added.

Apple had noted that its App Store is the safest way for users to access applications on its devices, and that the fees it charges helps ensure quality.

data.title: Keppel sets $100B interim FUM target by 2026, outlines new cost savings of $50M
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Keppel Ltd. (OTCPK:KPELF) Q4 2024

Management View

  • CEO Loh Chin Hua highlighted Keppel’s transformation into a global asset manager and operator, focusing on energy transition, digitalization, and alternative real assets. He noted that the company achieved $1.06 billion in net profit from continuing operations for FY 2024, a 5% increase compared to FY 2023.
  • The infrastructure segment delivered strong results, with earnings surging 4.9x from $137 million in FY 2021 to $673 million in FY 2024. Connectivity earnings grew by 45% year-over-year.
  • Asset management fees increased by 54% to $436 million in FY 2024, with funds under management rising from $55 billion to $88 billion. Keppel is targeting $100 billion in FUM by 2026 and $200 billion by 2030.
  • Free cash inflow for the year was $901 million, compared to a $384 million outflow in the prior year. The company also achieved $70 million in recurring annual cost savings ahead of schedule and set a new target of an additional $50 million in savings by 2026.
  • CFO Kevin Chng elaborated that recurring income accounted for 72% of net profit from continuing operations in FY 2024, reflecting improved earnings quality.

Outlook

  • Loh Chin Hua stated that Keppel is focused on achieving its $10 billion to $12 billion asset monetization target by 2026, with $7 billion already announced. Monetization efforts include legacy offshore and marine assets valued at $3.6 billion.
  • The company plans to double the gross power capacity of its data center portfolio to 1.2 gigawatts in the coming years, supported by $10 billion in expected new FUM from Keppel Data Center Fund III and other co-investments.
  • Keppel’s Infrastructure segment aims to leverage a $40 billion deal flow pipeline and $26 billion in dry powder to expand clean energy and decarbonization initiatives, including long-term contracts worth over $100 million in annual EBITDA starting 2025.
  • The company is also advancing two new subsea cable systems, focusing on connecting Southeast Asia to broader regions, and expects internal rate of returns in the mid-teens for these projects.

Financial Results

  • Net profit from continuing operations grew to $1.064 billion in FY 2024, up 5% from $1.015 billion in FY 2023. ROE improved to 10.1%.
  • The Connectivity segment reported a 45% increase in net profit to $184 million, driven by higher acquisition fees and improved data center performance.
  • The Real Estate segment recorded a net profit of $306 million, down 3% year-over-year, attributed to lower profits from trading projects in China and Singapore.
  • Free cash flow improved significantly, with net cash from operating activities rising to $200 million and net cash from investing activities reaching $701 million.
  • Dividend payout for FY 2024 totaled $0.34 per share, including a proposed final dividend of $0.19 per share.

Q&A

  • Zhiwei Foo, Macquarie Research, inquired about M1’s EBITDA growth and subsea cable project details. CEO Loh Chin Hua attributed M1’s growth to digitalization reducing costs, while emphasizing the focus on executing the Bifrost project by the second half of 2025. He highlighted expected IRRs above 30% for Bifrost and mid-teens for future systems.
  • Lim Siew Khee, CGS International, asked about valuation gains in Real Estate and progress on Asset Co monetization. CFO Kevin Chng noted valuation gains were driven by assets in Singapore and Vietnam, while Asset Co monetization efforts include bareboat charters and potential fund formation.
  • Brandon Lee, Citigroup Inc., questioned asset monetization targets and AI chip export restrictions. Management reiterated the $10 billion to $12 billion target and emphasized opportunities arising from AI democratization and cost reductions.
  • Felicia Tan, The Edge Singapore, asked about investor preferences and interest rate impacts. CEO Loh Chin Hua explained that Keppel’s strategy balances real asset ownership with fund management, while higher rates are already factored into underwriting models.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts raised questions about monetization targets, subsea cable expansion, and broader strategic initiatives, reflecting cautious optimism. Concerns about dividend consistency and legacy asset monetization were evident. Tone was slightly positive.
  • Management conveyed confidence in Keppel’s transformation, highlighting recurring income growth, infrastructure expansion, and progress on cost savings. Tone was confident, supported by specific forward-looking metrics.
  • Compared to earlier quarters, management appeared increasingly optimistic about achieving strategic milestones, while analysts maintained a neutral-to-slightly-positive stance, balancing opportunities and risks.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • No prior quarter data was provided for comparison.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management acknowledged challenges in monetizing legacy offshore and marine assets, stating efforts are underway to derisk the $3.6 billion portfolio.
  • Analysts expressed concerns about the competitive landscape for digital connectivity and potential valuation impacts from higher interest rates.
  • Real Estate development profits declined due to weaker market conditions in China and Singapore, though management aims to mitigate risks through asset-light strategies.

Final Takeaway

Keppel Ltd. reported strong financial results for Q4 2024, driven by growth in connectivity and infrastructure segments, alongside a significant increase in funds under management. The company remains focused on achieving its $10 billion to $12 billion asset monetization target by 2026 and expanding recurring income streams through investments in clean energy, digital infrastructure, and asset management. With a commitment to cost optimization and leveraging AI advancements, Keppel appears well-positioned to deliver value for its shareholders and limited partners.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Biggest stock movers Wednesday: GOOG, AMD, and more
data.description:
Stock futures edged lower Wednesday morning as trade tensions between the U.S. and China weighed on investor sentiment.

Here are some of Wednesday's biggest stock movers:

Biggest stock gainers

  • Shares of Snap (NYSE:SNAP) rose more than 5% after delivering strong Q4 results, with revenue rising ~15% Y/Y and daily active users up 9%. For Q1, the company guided revenue between $1.33B and $1.36B, surpassing estimates of $1.33B, but its adjusted EBITDA forecast of $40M–$75M fell short of the $79.9M consensus. The company expects daily active users to reach 459M in the current quarter.
  • Lumen Technologies (NYSE:LUMN) shares surged nearly 10% following upbeat Q4 results, driven by an 18.9% Y/Y rise in fiber broadband revenue within its Mass Markets segment and 42,000 Quantum Fiber customer additions, bringing total fiber-enabled homes to 4.16M by year-end. For FY2025, the company projects EBITDA between $3.2B and $3.4B and free cash flow of $700M to $900M. Lumen aims to achieve over $250M in run-rate cost savings by year-end, supporting its long-term goal of $1B in expense reductions by 2027. The company expects FY2025 capital expenditures in the range of $4.1B to $4.3B, with a focus on PCF contracts.
  • Enphase Energy (ENPH) shares climbed 8% after reporting better-than-expected Q4 results, with revenue rising 26.5% Y/Y. The company posted a GAAP gross margin of 51.8% and a non-GAAP gross margin of 53.2%, including a net IRA benefit of 13.5%. Free cash flow came in at $159.2M, with total liquidity of $1.72B. For Q1 2025, Enphase guided revenue between $340M and $380M, above the $340.91M consensus, including $50M in safe harbor revenue and shipments of 150–170 MWh of IQ Batteries. Non-GAAP gross margin is expected in the 48%–51% range, or 38%–41% excluding IRA benefits, with net IRA benefits projected at $36M–$39M based on 1.2M U.S.-manufactured microinverter shipments.

Biggest stock losers

  • Alphabet (NASDAQ:GOOG) (NASDAQ:GOOGL) shares tumbled nearly 7% after reporting mixed Q4 results, missing revenue expectations, and announcing a higher-than-expected $75B CapEx plan for FY2025, well above the $57.9B consensus. The company projects $16B–$18B in Q1 spending, with most investments directed toward AI-driven technical infrastructure, including servers and data centers. The company also warned of Q1 revenue headwinds from forex impacts and one fewer day of sales compared to the prior year, while also highlighting AI-driven growth in Search and Cloud, though Cloud revenue could see variability depending on new capacity rollouts.
  • Advanced Micro Devices (NASDAQ:AMD) shares plunged over 9% despite posting record Q4 2024 revenue growth of 24% Y/Y as investors reacted to slowing Data Center segment growth. While segment revenue surged 69% Y/Y, it marked the slowest increase in a year, down from 122% in Q3 and 114.5% in Q2. Weighing on sentiment, AMD’s Q1 revenue forecast of $6.8B–$7.4B, with a $7.1B midpoint slightly above the $7.04B consensus, failed to ease concerns over decelerating growth in its key business segment.

data.title: GSK reports Q4 results, raises long-term outlook
data.description:
• GSK press release (NYSE:GSK): Q4 Core EPS of 23.20 p.
  • Revenue of £8.11B (+0.7% Y/Y).
  • For FY : Total 2024 sales £31.4 billion +3% AER; +7% CER; Specialty Medicines sales +19%. HIV sales +13%. Oncology +98%. Respiratory/Immunology and Other +13%; Vaccines sales -4%. Shingrix +1% and Arexvy -51%; General Medicines sales +6%. Trelegy +27%.
  • FY Core EPS of 159.3p.
  • Expect 2025 turnover growth of between 3% to 5%; Core operating profit growth of between 6% to 8%; Core EPS growth of between 6% to 8%, including the expected benefit from the share buyback programme
  • 2031 sales outlook increased to more than £40 billion (previously >£38 billion), reflecting late-stage pipeline progress

data.title: UK's service activity drops in January
data.description:
The headline S&P Global UK Services PMI Business Activity Index registered 50.8in January, down fractionally from 51.1 in December and thejoint-lowest for 15 months.

Key findings include: Renewed downturn in order books; marginal output growth in January;fastest reduction in employment for four years.

January data highlighted a challenging businessenvironment for UK service providers as stagflationconditions appeared to take a firmer hold at the start of theyear. Output levels increased only marginally, while inputcost inflation accelerated for the fifth month in a row to itshighest since April 2024. Businesses widely noted sharplyrising salary payments and many also felt the impact ofsuppliers passing on forthcoming increases in employers'national insurance contributions." said Tim Moore, Economics Director at S&P Global MarketIntelligence.

ETFs: (FXB), (EWU), (FKU), (EWUS), (FLGB)

Currency: (GBP:USD)

data.title: Shopping on Shein, Temu could get costlier as U.S. ends trade loophole
data.description:
Americans may have to pay more when shopping on low-cost e-commerce platforms like Shein, Temu, AliExpress and Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN) Haul, as President Donald Trump ended a trade loophole for duty-free shipping of certain packages.

The trade exemption, called "de minimis," waived standard customs duties for shipping packages worth less than $800 to the U.S. De minimis shipments have swelled from about 139M in 2015 to over 1.36B in 2024.

The provision helped Chinese e-commerce platforms grow their market share in the U.S. through lower prices. Discount marketplace Temu, owned by PDD (NASDAQ:PDD), and fast fashion retailer Shein together likely accounted for more than 30% of all packages shipped to the U.S. daily under de minimis, the U.S. congressional committee on China noted in 2023.

The committee said nearly all products on Temu and Shein are valued under $800 and "can enter the U.S. uninspected and free from duties that most American clothing brands pay."

Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN) Haul, which launched in November, lists goods from China-based sellers priced $20 or less, although shipping times are longer. Ending de minimis is not expected to have a major impact on Amazon, as Haul is a relatively new and small business for the e-commerce giant.

Meanwhile, Shein and Temu have taken steps to offset the impact, such as sourcing more products from outside China and opening warehouses in the U.S.

"So the lifting of de minimis will not impact 100% of the products they sell in the U.S.," Juozas Kaziukenas, CEO of e-commerce data firm Marketplace Pulse, told Reuters. "It will have an impact, but it's not going to be the end of the reign of Shein and Temu."

But small and medium-sized online retailers that source products from China are expected to be the most affected, as they have fewer resources to diversify their supply chain.

According to industry associations, de minimis packages could double in price if the loophole ended. "This added cost would feed inflation in the form of a massive, regressive tax hike on American consumers."

data.title: European markets dip amid escalating trade tensions, and earnings flurry
data.description:
London (UKX) -0.08%

Germany (DAX:IND) -0.42% Germany's service activity growth hits six-month high.

France (CAC:IND) -0.27% France service activity falls in January. Industrial production fell 0.4% M/M in December.

Iceland’s Central Bank cut its key interest rate by 50 bps to 8.0%, aligning with market expectations.

The Services PMI in Sweden fell to 50.1 in January

Spain's service PMI drops in January.

Retail sales in the Czech Republic advanced by 6.2% Y/Y in December.

The pan-European Stoxx 600 (STOXX) climbed 0.06% as investors watched escalated trade tensions between U.S. and China.

In corporate news, Novo Nordisk posted stronger-than-expected profits for Q4 driven by a 107% surge in sales of its Wegovy weight loss drug. Among other companies posting earnings include: Banco Santander (SAN), Credit Agricole, GSK (GSK), Handelsbanken, and TotalEnergies. TotalEnergies (TTE) beat top-line and bottom-line estimates; initiates FY25 outlook.

Coming up in the next session: UK Services PMI expected shortly.

In the bond market, the U.S. 10-year Treasury yield down 8 basis points to 4.54%.

Germany's 10-year yield unchanged at 2.51%.

UK's 10-year yield was down 4 basis points to 4.59%.
